column2: The lower tiers of the Chinese Bureaucracy, and the administration of various other realms that have modelled their.

Though not going so far as to claim the Mandate of Heaven, rulers with the Eastern Imperial government emulate the Chinese Imperial system even more thoroughly than those with the Confucian Bureaucracy government.

Though taking some inspiration from the Chinese Imperial government, the Japanese Imperial government is structured somewhat differently and has discarded the concept of the Mandate of Heaven, seeing the Imperial Family's right to keep the Chrysanthemum Throne as unquestionable... but the extent to which the Tenno should be permitted to get involved in actually ruling the realm as something that can be questioned.

Greatly inspired by the government system of the Tang dynasty, the Japanese Bureaucracy government is supposed to be a bureaucratic meritocracy, but many see it as just a stepping stone on the way to something more feudal and more hereditary.
While closer to regular feudalism than Chinese Imperial, the Japanese Feudal government retains some features from the latter.
The Japanese Monastic Feudal government is unique among the Japanese governments in that it allows the holder to demand religious conversion and to revoke titles from many non-co-religionists.
Copying the Japanese Imperial government of the Tenno for the most part, the Divine Imperial government is partially bureaucratic and partially theocratic.
